    Summary of the Stan Model

    model.Rmd

    Introduction

    This document provides a summary of a hierarchical statistical model of antibody kinetics, implemented in Stan. The model is designed to analyse longitudinal titre data, accounting for boosting and waning effects over time. It incorporates individual-level random effects and covariate influences on key model parameters. A full description of the model can be found in the supplementary material in the published paper using the methods described here: Russell TW et al.Â Real-time estimation of immunological responses against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants in the UK: a mathematical modelling study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2024 Sep 11:S1473-3099(24)00484-5.

    Usage Notes

    This model is suitable for analysing longitudinal titre data with either lower, upper, both (or no) censoring and incorporates both individual-level variability and arbitrary regression structure to adjust for covariates. Users can adapt the model by specifying appropriate covariates via a R style linear model formula, priors, and data inputs relevant to their study.

    Model Specification

    Overview

    The model describes the expected log-transformed titre value Î¼n\mu_{n} for individual nn at time tnt_n and titre type kk, using a piecewise linear function to capture boosting and waning phases:

    • Boosting Phase: For tn<tp,nt_n < t_{p,n}, the titre increases at rate m1,nm_{1,n}.
    • Plateau Phase: For tp,nâ‰¤tnâ‰¤ts,nt_{p,n} \leq t_n \leq t_{s,n}, the titre remains elevated.
    • Waning Phase: For tn>ts,nt_n > t_{s,n}, the titre decreases at rate m3,nm_{3,n}.

    Mathematical Formulation

    Expected Titre Value

    The expected log-transformed titre value Î¼n\mu_{n} is given by:

    Î¼n=t0,n+{m1,nâ‹…tn,if tn<tp,nm1,nâ‹…tp,n+m2,nâ‹…(tnâˆ’tp,n),if tp,nâ‰¤tnâ‰¤ts,nm1,nâ‹…tp,n+m2,nâ‹…(ts,nâˆ’tp,n)+m3,nâ‹…(tnâˆ’ts,n),if tn>ts,n \mu_{n} = t_{0,n} + \begin{cases} m_{1,n} \cdot t_n, & \text{if } t_n < t_{p,n} \\ m_{1,n} \cdot t_{p,n} + m_{2,n} \cdot (t_n - t_{p,n}), & \text{if } t_{p,n} \leq t_n \leq t_{s,n} \\ m_{1,n} \cdot t_{p,n} + m_{2,n} \cdot (t_{s,n} - t_{p,n}) + m_{3,n} \cdot (t_n - t_{s,n}), & \text{if } t_n > t_{s,n} \end{cases}

    where:

    • t0,nt_{0,n}: Baseline titre level for individual nn and titre type kk.
    • tp,nt_{p,n}: Time to peak titre for individual nn and titre type kk.
    • ts,nt_{s,n}: Time to start of waning for individual nn and titre type kk.
    • m1,nm_{1,n}: Boosting rate for individual nn and titre type kk.
    • m2,nm_{2,n}: Plateau rate (assumed to be zero in this model).
    • m3,nm_{3,n}: Waning rate for individual nn and titre type kk.
    • tnt_n: Observation time for individual nn.
    • Î¼nâ‰¥0\mu_{n} \geq 0: Ensured by taking the maximum with zero.

    Observation Model

    The observed log-transformed titre values yny_n are modeled as:

    ynâˆ¼Normal(Î¼n,Ïƒ) y_n \sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{n}, \sigma)

    where Ïƒ\sigma is the measurement error standard deviation.

    Censoring

    The model accounts for left-censoring and right-censoring:

    • Left-Censoring: For observations below detection limit LL, the likelihood contribution is:

      P(ynâ‰¤L)=Î¦(Lâˆ’Î¼nÏƒ) P(y_n \leq L) = \Phi\left(\dfrac{L - \mu_{n}}{\sigma}\right)

    • Right-Censoring: For observations above detection limit UU, the likelihood contribution is:

      P(ynâ‰¥U)=1âˆ’Î¦(Uâˆ’Î¼nÏƒ) P(y_n \geq U) = 1 - \Phi\left(\dfrac{U - \mu_{n}}{\sigma}\right)

    where Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution.

    Hierarchical Structure

    Individual-Level Parameters

    For each individual nn and titre type kk, the parameters are modeled as:

    t0,n=t0,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒt0+Ïƒt0,kâ‹…zt0,ntp,n=tp,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒtp+Ïƒtp,kâ‹…ztp,nts,n=tp,n+Î”ts,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒts+Ïƒts,kâ‹…zts,nm1,n=m1,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒm1+Ïƒm1,kâ‹…zm1,nm2,n=m2,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒm2+Ïƒm2,kâ‹…zm2,nm3,n=m3,k+ğ±nâŠ¤ğ›ƒm3+Ïƒm3,kâ‹…zm3,n \begin{aligned} t_{0,n} &= t_{0,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{t_0} + \sigma_{t_0,k} \cdot z_{t_0,n} \\ t_{p,n} &= t_{p,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{t_p} + \sigma_{t_p,k} \cdot z_{t_p,n} \\ t_{s,n} &= t_{p,n} + \Delta t_{s,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{t_s} + \sigma_{t_s,k} \cdot z_{t_s,n} \\ m_{1,n} &= m_{1,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{m_1} + \sigma_{m_1,k} \cdot z_{m_1,n} \\ m_{2,n} &= m_{2,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{m_2} + \sigma_{m_2,k} \cdot z_{m_2,n} \\ m_{3,n} &= m_{3,k} + \mathbf{x}_n^\top \boldsymbol{\beta}_{m_3} + \sigma_{m_3,k} \cdot z_{m_3,n} \end{aligned}

    where:

    • ğ±n\mathbf{x}_n: Covariate vector for individual nn.
    • ğ›ƒâ‹…\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\cdot}: Regression coefficients for the corresponding parameter.
    • Ïƒâ‹…,k\sigma_{\cdot,k}: Standard deviation of individual-level random effects for titre type kk.
    • zâ‹…,nâˆ¼Normal(0,1)z_{\cdot,n} \sim \text{Normal}(0, 1): Standard normal random variables.

    Population-Level Parameters

    The population-level parameters for each titre type kk have the following priors:

    T0p,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼t0,Ïƒt0)tpp,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼tp,Ïƒtp)Î”tp,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼tsâˆ’Î¼tp,Ïƒts)m1p,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼m1,Ïƒm1)m2p,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼m2,Ïƒm2)m3p,kâˆ¼Normal(Î¼m3,Ïƒm3) \begin{aligned} T_0^{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{t_0}, \sigma_{t_0}) \\ t_p^{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{t_p}, \sigma_{t_p}) \\ \Delta t_{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{t_s} - \mu_{t_p}, \sigma_{t_s}) \\ m_1^{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{m_1}, \sigma_{m_1}) \\ m_2^{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{m_2}, \sigma_{m_2}) \\ m_3^{p,k} &\sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{m_3}, \sigma_{m_3}) \end{aligned}

    The standard deviations of the individual-level random effects have priors:

    Ïƒkâˆ¼Normal(0,Ïƒp) \sigma_{k} \sim \text{Normal}(0, \sigma_{p})

    Regression Coefficients

    The regression coefficients have the following priors:

    ğ›ƒâ‹…âˆ¼Normal(ğŸ,ÏƒÎ²â‹…) \boldsymbol{\beta}_{\cdot} \sim \text{Normal}(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\beta_{\cdot}})

    with appropriate constraints for parameters that must be positive or negative.

    Data and Parameters

    Data Inputs

    • NN: Total number of observations.
    • KK: Number of titre types.
    • tnt_n: Observation times.
    • yny_n: Observed log-transformed titre values.
    • ğ±n\mathbf{x}_n: Covariate vector for each individual.
    • Censoring indicators for left and right censoring.

    Parameters to Estimate

    • Population-level parameters: t0,kt_{0,k}, tp,kt_{p,k}, Î”ts,k\Delta t_{s,k}, m1,km_{1,k}, m2,km_{2,k}, m3,km_{3,k}.
    • Individual-level random effects: zâ‹…,nz_{\cdot,n}.
    • Regression coefficients: ğ›ƒâ‹…\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\cdot}.
    • Measurement error standard deviation: Ïƒ\sigma.

    Priors

    The prior distributions are specified based on previous studies and domain knowledge:

    • Population Means: Specified using normal distributions with means Î¼â‹…\mu_{\cdot} and standard deviations Ïƒâ‹…\sigma_{\cdot}.
    • Random Effect Standard Deviations: Weakly informative normal priors centered at zero.
    • Regression Coefficients: Weakly informative normal priors centered at zero.
    • Measurement Error: Ïƒâˆ¼Normal(0,2)\sigma \sim \text{Normal}(0, 2), constrained to be positive.

    Likelihood

    The likelihood function combines the observation model with the censoring mechanisms:

    For uncensored observations:ynâˆ¼Normal(Î¼n,Ïƒ)For left-censored observations:P(ynâ‰¤L)=Î¦(Lâˆ’Î¼nÏƒ)For right-censored observations:P(ynâ‰¥U)=1âˆ’Î¦(Uâˆ’Î¼nÏƒ) \begin{aligned} &\text{For uncensored observations:} \quad y_n \sim \text{Normal}(\mu_{n}, \sigma) \\ &\text{For left-censored observations:} \quad P(y_n \leq L) = \Phi\left(\dfrac{L - \mu_{n}}{\sigma}\right) \\ &\text{For right-censored observations:} \quad P(y_n \geq U) = 1 - \Phi\left(\dfrac{U - \mu_{n}}{\sigma}\right) \end{aligned}
